p.seg: The gentleman checks his desires by repressing his feelings of anger.
"When the petty men resent you and revile you,
then as an emperor you must naturally go on to be diligently virtuous.
"...not only does he not presume to harbour anger."
"...you should make your mind tolerant and spatious."
King Chéng (ca. 1042 B.C. - ca. 1021 B.C.) said to Jūn Chén:
"It is necessary to show forbearance,
and it is then that one will succeed.
When one broad-minded,
then one's virtue will be large.
ZUO Xuan 15
The proverb says,
"Elevatedness and baseness depend on the mind,
streams and marshes will attract dirt,
mountains and marshes bear sickness in them,
jades hide jade faults,
the ruler of a state must exercise forbearance vis-a-vis vilification:
such is the Way of Heaven.
-ZUO Zhao 1
"Lǔ ran its state on the basis of mutual tolerance."
"If you cannot put up with one humiliation
are you going to feel bad about it for the rest of your life?" (Compare ZUO Zhao 31 一之不忍，而終身乎？懼內)
- Zuǒzhuàn, Āi 27
The Earl of Zhì (died 453 B.C.) entered the outer gates of Nánlǐ
he ordered Zhào Mèng to enter the place.
Zhào Mèng replied:
"You are here yourself. (So why don't YOU go?)"
The Earl of Zhì said:
"Ugly and chicken-livered as you are,
how on earth did you ever become the head of your clan?"
He replied:
"By being able to suffer humiliating insult.
Presumably I shall not be doing the Zhào clan any harm this way!"
When King Zhuāng of Chǔ (reigned 613 - 659) attacked Zhèng
the Earl of Zhèng, bare-chested, pulled along a sheep to welcome him.
King Zhuāng said:
"This ruler is capable of showing proper regard for others.
He is bound to be reliable in the employment of his people."
"If one cannot bear with one shameful humiliation
how about the life-long humiliations."
Confucius said:
"When there is a failure of tolerant forbearance in small matters
then this will ruin a large strategy."
A fit of anger one morning
neglecting one's own person and negatively affecting one's nearest kin,
is not that confusion?" [Note the connection with anger.]
"The gentleman is nowhere competitive"
"The gentleman is quite confident but not competitive."
Zēngzǐ, when offended against, did not retaliate.
[The refusal to assert oneself combatively. What is needed is moral self-assurance. Compare the American way of using the word "aggressive"
not retaliate when offended.]
The Master admonished Zǐlù:
"The teeth are hard, so they get broken,
the tongue is soft, so it persists.
The soft is bound to win over the hard,
the weak is bound to win over the strong.
He who is fond of fighting is bound to get injured,
he who loves bravery is bound to perish.
Among the basic points about all manner of action
forbearance is the supreme.
Lǎozǐ said:
"Understanding the male
guard the female;
understanding the white,
guard the black."
And he also said:
"The supremely straight is as if crooked,
the supremely wise is as if inept,
the supremely eloquent is as if tongue-tied."
LAO 73
Superior excellence is like (that of ) water.
The excellence of water profits all creatures and does not compete over them.
It also says:
"The Way of Heaven does not compete, but it is good at winning the day;
it does not speak but it is good at responding.
Xúnzǐ said: (4.1.1)
"Words that harm others
go deeper than spears and lances." (1. don't use such words; 2. when others use them show forbearance with respect to them.)
Lìn Xiāngrú (Warring States personality from Zhào with famous biography in Shǐjì 史記) said:
"When two tigers fight with each other
the situation is such that they cannot both survive."
Wáng Jiè of Jìn dynasty times (Morohashi 07730) once said:
"Man has his imperfections:
one should heartily forgive him."
"When dealing with someone who is wrong,
one should berate him according to principles>reason.
Throughout one's life one should never show delight or perturbation on one's face."
When Cáo Cān (died 190 B.C.) was prime minister
the back garden of his home was close to the home of a magistrate.
There was drinking and shouting carousal there, day and night.
The magistrate was upset by this situation
and he lead Cáo Cān to the park,
???The prime minister summoned the carousers
and inquired about the carousals.??? [It seems that something is wrong with the text here. I understand nothing.]
Then Cáo Cān returned to his own place,
and, when he sat alone and drank wine in his tent,
he sang a song and responded with shouts to boot. (Thus making it appear that this was normal in the neighbourhood...)
When he saw minor flaws in others
he covered them up and hid them, put a lid over them.
When Bīng Jí (of Western Hàn times) was prime minister
the minister of justice 御史 kept drinking himself silly,
and Xī Cáo was going to take him to court.
Bīng Jí said:
"If you noisily accuse others of drinking or eating too much,
where do you want them to turn?
All they do is to throw up on my carriage mat!"
So Xī Cáo put up with him for the time being.
When Zhāng Liáng (chief advisor of Hàn Gāozǔ Liú Bāng, died 189 B.C.) fled into hiding
at one point he was travelling at his leisure through Xiàpí.
On the bridge there there was an old man
who was wearing a unadorned coarse-cloth jacket.
He went over to where Zhāng Liáng was standing
and popped his sandals off the bridge.
Then he turned to Zhāng Liáng and said:
"Little man!
get down there (into the muck) to fetch the sandals!"
Zhāng Liáng was stunned.
With great effort he showed forbearance,
and got down to fetch the sandals.
then he prostrated himsel to offer them up to their owner.
The old man received them with his feet and said: "That little fellow is capable to learning his lesson!"
Hán Xìn (Early Western Hàn important general) was in the habit of wearing a long sword on his body.
In the market place a young man insulted him,
saying:
"You're wearing the long sword, sir,
are you capable of killing a man?
If you can kill a man
then go ahead and kill me.
If you cannot kill a man,
then why don't you crawl under my crutch!"
Hán Xìn bent down
and crawled along between his legs.
Hàn Gāozǔ
appointed Hán Xìn "leading general",
and Hán Xìn summoned the young man from the market place
and told him:
"The other year you humiliated me.
Today, are you going to humiliate me?"
The young man begged to have his life spared,
and Hán Xìn not only let him off
but conferred the office of a supervisor on him. (The young man had shown extraordinary wit and courage. the office here conferred seems to have existed only from Three Kingdoms times onwards.)
Zhí Bùyí (of Hàn times, Morohashi 88304) shared a house with a certain Mr. Láng.
Someone who was saying farewell
took Láng's money along, by mistake,
and the owner of the money suspected Zhí Bùyí of the theft.
Bùyí offered his apologies,
[[[I do not understand this line CHECK VARIOUS OLD EDITIONS]]] (?????)
and did pay him back the amount that had disappeared.
Afterwards, the man who had said farewell arrived back,
and returned the lost money.
Láng was terribly ashamed.
Because of this episode he was called a superior man.
Hán Ānguó (Western Hàn polititian of Wǔdì's time, Morohashi 12801) held the office of nèishǐ in Liáng,
He fell foul of the law and ended up in prison.
He was insulted/humiliated by a prison official by the name of Tián Jiǎ.
Hán Ānguó said:
"Will cold ash (someone whose days of power are past) still sometimes burn or not?"
Tián Jiǎ said:
"If cold ash is burning
I'll piss on it." (is the point that this is an impolite answer? what EXACTLY is going on?)
At a later stage
Hán Ānguó was released
and he was appointed governor in Liáng Province.
Tián Jiǎ, terrified, left the province.
Hán Ānguó said:
"If he leaves
I shall punish his relatives down to the ninth degree.
If he does not leave
I shall pardon his crime."
Tián Jiǎ then went to pay a visit to Hán Ānguó,
and Hán Ānguo said:
"Today, the cold ashes have caught fire.
Why aren't you pissing on them?"
Tián Jiǎ was terrified.
Hán Ānguó pardoned his crime
and he conferred on Tián Jiǎ the office of Village Chief Officer.
Chén Zhòng (famous scholar of later Hàn dynasty times, Morohashi 12412) shared living quarters with Láng.
Someone, upon taking his leave from Chén Zhòng's house to attend a funeal,
by mistake walked away with neighbour Láng's trousers.
The owner of the trousers, Láng, suspected that Chén Zhòng had taken them.
Chén Zhòng did not explain himself.
He bought a new pair of trousers to "return" them to their rightful owner.
Liú Kuān (polititian under 漢桓帝劉志（132年－167年）was a kind-hearted and forgiving person.
Although he was hot-tempered, he never spoke rashly or changed his facial expression quickly.
His wife wanted to test him out.
She used the opportunity where he was all dressed up for court,
and she ordered a maid to hand him some congee and pour it all over his court dress.
But Liú Kuān's facial expression did not change one bit.
Liú Kuān gave the maid a slow concerned look and asked:
"Has the congee soiled your hands?"
Zhuō Mào (high official of Western Hàn times, GYCD: 54 BC to A.D. 28)
was by nature open-minded, kind-hearted and respectful to others,
he was fond of old friends from his province,
and even those whose practices were not like those of Zhuō Mào
they all loved him, admired him, and were truly fond of him.
One day he went out
and there was a man who was sure that Zhuō's horse was his own.
Zhuō Mào knew perfectly well in his mind that the man was mistaken,
but without saying a word he untied his horse and gave it to the man.
Some time afterwards
the owner of the horse had found the horse elsewhere
and sent Zhuō Mào's horse back,
apologising for it.
Zhuō Mào's refusal to pick fights was like this.
At one point Liú Líng (famous scholar and drukard of Jìn times, dates unclear) was drunk (See 世說新語)
and he got into a fight with a vulgar fellow.
That man thrust forward his sleeves and charged forth, shaking his fists.
Liú Líng said:
"My chicken-breast is no match for your distinguished fist."
The man burst out laughing and stopped his attack.
(The Táng dynasty general) Lóu Shīdé was a profound person of stature (what the French call "envergure"),
and his disciple Chú was governor in Dài Province.
When Chú was about to leave to take up his office
Lóu Shīdé said:
"My own job is Assistant to the Prime Minister
and on top of that you become the Province head.
Our distinguished positions are indeed excessive.
This is what people will envy us for.
How can we try to avoid (damaging conflicts with those who are so envious of us)?"
The disciple knelt down upright on the floor:
"From now on, even if someone spits me in the face
I will just wipe it off.
Presumably, I will cause you no worry."
Lóu Shīdé looked very much concerned and said:
"This way you give me plenty to worry about.
If someone else spits you in the face,
this is because he is angry at you.
If you wipe it off
then you go against his intentions,
and thereby you will aggravate his anger.
You should not wipe it away and let it dry off all by itself,
you should smilingly suffer the humiliation."
Zhāng Quánwēng (待考) said:
In Lù Province there was a peasant
in whose home five generations lived together.
The Táng emperor Tàizōng (Lǐ Shìmín), during his campain in Bìng Province,
passed by his home,
and he summoned the family head out
and demanded to know:
"By what method have you got to this stage?"
He replied:
"I have no other method than this one:
I just am able to practise forbearance, that is all"
Lǐ Shìmín considered the man was right.
Zhāng Gōngyì (Táng dynasty scholar, GYCD: dating unclear) lived with nine generations in the same house.
Emperor Gāozōng went to visit him.
When the emperor asked about the background of this.
he wrote down the character "forbearance", by way of an answer.
The Son of Heaven shed tears
and gave him a present of precious silk.
Lǐ Bì and Dòu Cān thought very highly of Lǐ Jífǔ's talents (all courtiers of 唐德宗 (742年－805年) times)
and they treated him very well.
Prime minister Lù Zhì (academician under Dézōng) suspected factionalism in this.
He rusticated Lǐ Jífǔ to become Chief Prosecutor in Míng Province.
When prime minister Lù Zhì himself was rusticated to Zhōng province
his successor, the new Prime Minister wanted to harm him
and he raised Lǐ Jífǔ to the post of governor of Zhōng Province,
and he ordered him to do as he wished (with his enemy the former prime minister Lù Zhì).
But when Lù Zhì arrived in Zhōng Province
Lǐ Jífǔ set aside his grievance against Lù Zhì and became best friends with him.
Others were impressed by Lǐ Jífǔ's broad-mindedness.
Péi Xíngjiǎn (GYCD: 619-682, scholar and philosopher, and famous general) once had conferred upon him (by the emperor) a horse with a precious saddle.
He ordered one of his empoyees to take the horse through its paces.
The horse stumbled and fell, the saddle was ruined.
That employee got scared and fled,
but Péi Xíngjiǎn called him back,
and he said:
"(Look!) I'm not going to make a legal case of this."
Wáng Shǒuhé (Morohashi 6658), minister under the Táng dynasty,
never picked quarrels with others.
At one point he wrote the character for "forbearance" between his writing desks,
and even on his curtains and the like
he placed embroidered pictures with this character.
The Táng emperor Lǐ Lōngjī knew his name, and found it at variance with the times.
He called up Wáng Shǒuhé to ask him to explain himself (about his name):
"Your name (already) means 'guarding harmony',
so one knows that you are not given to quarrelling.
But when you love to write the character rěn 忍 'forbearance' so much
you do show your way of thinking even more!"
Wáng Shǒuhé submitted the following response:
"I have heard it said
if one is rigid, one will break,
if one is hard, one will get broken,
in all matters
it is forbearance that is supreme."
The emperor said:
"Good!"
And he gave him silk to make a banner with. (guess what this banner would be inscribed with!)
When Péi Xíngjiǎn (GYCD: 619-682, scholar and philosopher, and famous general) first brought peace to Dūzhīzhépū,
he captured precious stones in vast numbers.
The generals and officers of the barbarians came to look at these,
and since Péi Xíngjiǎn was an extravagant person
he showed them to all his visitors.
There was one agate platter, two chǐ large,
beautifully patterned and glittering,
a minor military officer rushing along, stumbled
the platter was smashed,
and the was scared.
He kowtowed so hard that blood stained the floor,
but Xíngjiǎn smiled and said:
"It is not as if you did this deliberately!"
On his face there was not the slightest trace of miserliness.
Xǔ Wéishī (served as prime minister under Táng Gāozōng 唐高宗 (628年—683年））was governor of Xiāng Province.
He governed his subordinates with generous tolerance.
When (at one point) someone had accepted bribes
Yuánshī did not have the heart to apply the law to him.
The culprit was so ashamed of himself
that he later mended his ways,
and he changed so as to become a morally impeccable official.
Lóu Shīdé of Táng times
was a profound personality of broad-minded stature (with what the French call "envergure").
If someone was in conflict with him
he was just compliant so as to avoid conflict,
and he did not show his reactions on his face.
One day, he was walking about together with Lǐ Zhāodé
and Lóu Shīdé was basically a very fat man,
and he was unable to walk fast.
Lǐ Zhāodé found that too slow
and he said angrily:
"It's the company of those people in the fields and huts that tempts you, I suppose?"
Shīdé replied with a smile:
"If I don't "do the fields and huts", (i.e. associate with the common peasants 王維 《送孟六歸襄陽》詩：醉歌田舍酒，笑讀古人書。
then who is supposed to do it?"
Before Dí Rénjié (630 -700, famous minister under Wǔ Zétiān 武則天) got involved with government (as prime minister)
Lóu Shīdé was already congratulating him.
The empress Wú Zétiān said:
"The reason why I've used you
was because Lóu Shīdé recommended you.
For that man truly does understand people."
And (indiscreetly) she took out Lóu Shīdé's letter.
Dí Rénjié was reduced to shame,
and in the end he sighed and said:
"Mr Lóu is a man of great virtue.
He has shown lenience towards me.
I know that I am far from reaching his levels."
Chén Qiān of Jìn times
was a man of pondus and of wisdom,
and from his youth he was a man of broadness of mind.
He excercised patient tolerance, and tended to hide people's faults (rather than blaming people for these),
and wherever he went he left achievements behind.
Jiǎ Gěng of Táng times,
after returning home to his residence
was receiving official guests,
tirelessly all day long.
His family members and his close associates
never saw him with a pleased or angy expression on his face.
As for the men of superior character and pure virtue in antiquity
what have they to add to this? (Jiǎ Gěng is as remarkable as any of these.)
Dù Yǎn (of Sòng times Morohashi 5863) said:
"Officials, these days, mostly will blame people for minor matters,
this is truly a case of a failure to show forgiveness."
From Dù Yǎn's exercise of his authority of governor of his Province,
to redeploying or taking care of officials,
he never did rude harm to any of these.
If any of these did not do their jobs, he would set them other tasks
and see to it that they did not go lazy.
If they were careless, he would instruct them on the impact on everyone's fortune.
There was no need to put them in fetters by means of the law.
At one time Fàn Zhòngyǎn was disagreeing on things with Dù Yǎn,
and he went so far as to attack Dù Yǎn verbally,
but Yǎn did not resent him for that reason (such was his virtue of forbearance).
Chén Shí (GYCD: 104-186), whose given name was Zhònggōng, was the head of Tàiqiū district.
Once somebody was hiding on a beam in his house, and ChénShí noticed the thief.
He called up his son and instructed him as follows:
"This unhappy fellow
is not necessarily basically of the evil kind.
It is just through habitual practice that his (current evil) nature comes about.
(For all we know) this is a case of "a superior man up on a beam". (Chén Shí is joking, of course.)
Suddenly he heard how the thief jump down with a thud, and then he saw him kneel down to beg forgiveness.
Chén Shí said:
"When I looked at you, I thought your shape was not that of a wicked person,
presumably it is all because of poverty and difficult circumstances (that you have come to this).
He gave him two pieces of cloth,
and told him to mend his ways. (Extraordinary position of the 之!)
Afterwards the man never engaged in thievery again.
Kǒng Mín from Huáinán (so far unidentified)
lived as an earnest recluse
and he never took office all his life.
His impeccable comportment kept very high standards.
At one point somone was stealing a bamboo tree from his garden.
Mín worried that in crossing the stream (bordering on his garden) the thief might catch a cold,
so he set up a little plank "bridge" to let him get across.
Generalising from this episode one may understand how he cared for other people.
Niú Hóng, Chief Secretary of the Administation in Suí dynasty times (Morohashi 07520)
had a brother by the name of Bì who was fond of alcohol and indeed addicted to it.
Once, when he was under the influence, he shot at a buffalo that was pulling a carriage belonging to Niú Hóng.
Niú Hóng returned to his home
and his wife welcomed him saying:
"My uncle has shot dead our buffalo."
When Niú Hóng heard this he was in no way surprised,
and he immediatedly said: "Well then, let us make dried meat of it.'
When he had sat down properly, his wife went on again:
"My uncle has carelessly shot and killed that buffalo.
That's an extrardinary thing to go ahead and do!"
Niú Hóng said: "I know, I know!"
His facial expression did not change.
He read his book, unflappable.
Chén Zhòng (an Eastern Hàn person famous for the high moral standards he aspired to), whose given name was Jǐnggōng,
was filial and uncorruptible in his comportment,
and he was employed in a public office.
One of his colleagues in the office owed away a debt of a hundred thousand cash,
and the creditor was turning up in the office every day (to ask for his money back).
But his requests led nowhere.
Then Chén Zhòng secretly returned the money in his colleague's stead. (He sympathised with the creditor.)
The colleague later realised what had happened, and profusely apologised to him.
Chén Zhòng said:
"It wasn't me!
Must have been someone with the same name and surname."
Never in his life did he speak about generosity. (He just practised it.)
Cáo Jié (a gentleman from Eastern Hàn times) was basically a kind-hearted and a generous man.
A neighbour had lost a pig,
and that pig was very much like Cáo Jié's own pigs.
The neighbour went over to Cáo Jié and recognised one as his own.
Cáo Jié never argued about the matter.
Later, the lost pig returned to its owner of its own accord,
and the neighbour felt greatly ashamed.
He sent over the pig he had recognised as his own and at the same time apologised.
Cáo Jié received his pig back with a smile (as if nothing had happened. (He did not celebrate his moral triumph).
Zhào Yuèdào (outspoken courtier of Sòng times, opponent of Wáng Ānshí 王安石) became Transport Commissioner at Chéngdū.
Once he went out,
and all he took along was one lute and one tortoise.
Wherever he sat down, he looked at his tortoise and strummed on his lute.
At one point he was scaling Mount Qīngshān
where he ran into a snowstorm.
He spent the night in a hostel,
and the people in the hostel had no idea that he was a commissioner.
One of them was quite rude to him.
But, unperturbed, Zhào Yuè kept strumming on his lute, and he made no fuss.
Fàn Chúnrén (second son of the famous writer and Sòng courtier Fàn Zhòngyǎn 范仲淹989 -1052) once said:
"All that I have learnt,
i honest effort and forgiveness, these two things.
In my whole life I cannot use them enough.
Even when I stand up at court and serve the ruler,
when I receive colleagues and friends,
when I cultivate close relations with members of my own amily,
I never deviate from these values for as much as a second."
He also admonished the young people in his household,
"Even the most stupid of people show great intelligence when they blame others,
and even the most intelligent people show great obtuseness as they show forgiveness towards themselves.
Now you folks should always blame yourselves in the spirit that one is wont to use when blaming others,
and you should forgive others in the spirit that one is wont to use when forgiving oneself.
Don't you then worry about not reaching the status of sages and worthies.
Chief of Staff Wáng Dàn (of Sòng times, Morohashi 07755) recommended Kòu Láigōng as prime minister,
but Kòu Láigōng maligned the Chief of Staff several times in front of the emperor,
whereas the Chief of Staff only had the highest praise for the other man.
One day the emperor said to the Chief of Staff:
"You may praise his admirable points,
but this man speaks ill of you, you know!"
The Chief of Staff said:
"That is fair enough.
I've been in the prime minister's office for a long time.
There must be many things that I've got wrong.
Kòu Láigōng would hide nothing in front of Your Majesty.
He thus shows honest loyal effort.
That is why I appreciate the man!"
Because of this the emperor appreciated the worth of the Chief of Staff even more.
Wáng Ānshí's (the famous Sòng dynasty reformer) younger brother was irremedially reckless in his ways,
One day after mid-winter
they made sacrifices of wine in the ancestral temple and laid out one hundred ritual vessels in front of the main hall.
and this reckless younger brother knocked all those vessels over.
Everyone in the family was shocked.
Unforeseen, Wáng Ānshí himself came back from an errand outside.
he saw the wine all over the floor, even all over the street,
so much so that one could not even walk properly.
But about all this Wáng Ānshí did not utter a word.
He just pulled up his garment and stepped (across the wine) and into the hall.
After the event, Wáng Ānshí's younger brother suddenly came to his senses,
and he turned into a decent man.
On this, again, Wáng Ānshí still had no comment.
Hán Wèi (of early Táng times) was a man of serious purpose, and broad-minded.
There was nothing he did not tolerate, and he was all at his ease in his study.
Hán Wèi was held in high esteem all over the world.
Together with Wáng Gōngchén as well as minister of justice Yè Dìngjī.
he set out for the city of Kāifēng in order to present himself for the examinations.
Wáng Gōngchén and Yè Dìngjī, at the time, were quarrelling fiercely
and Hán Wèi was sitting behind his curtain looking over examination books, pretending not to hear.
Wáng Gōngchén got overexcited and did not know what to do, and went to Hán Wèi room and said to him:
"Working up your qualifications, eh?"
Hán Wèi apologised mildly (and pretended he had heard nothing).
When he had been on a punitive mission in Shǎnxi Province
at the time Yán Shīlǔ and Lǐ Yīnggōng were (also) not getting along with each other.
Yán Shīlǔ was then discussing Lǐ Yīnggōng's ways with Hán Wèi in the latter's place,
and similarly Yán Shīlù was discussing Yán Shīlù's ways with the same Hán Wèi, and Hán Wèi did not take sides.
When Ōuyáng Xiū (the famous Sòng dynasty man of letters) held office,
whenever there was someone who did not conform to his principles,
he would invariably confront them.
As a result, people would often resent him.
Hán Wèigōng was an exception:
he would freely instruct Ōuyáng Xiū
on principles that were unacceptable to the man.
Ōuyáng Xiū never confronted him, using his authority. (He showed tolereance for free straightforwardness.)
Hán Wèigōng (of Sòng times) said:
"It is no good to seek to keep petty men at a distance.
In a village of three families there will be one such family of petty people.
The thing to do is to handle these in a principled way.
If one understands that they are petty people,
then one must deal with them as petty people.
One must have no further intimate contact with them.
If one has intimate contact with them
then one will oneself become petty.
If other people criticise and malign one
one must just reflect on oneself to be sure whether one is right
or whether one is in fact NOT right.
Then the right will be on one's own side, and the injustice on the other party.
What use is it to insist on settling scores with anyone?
Whenever a person's talk reaches something he finds unjust
then his vital energies are aroused
his facial expression will change,
his words will become violent.
Only Hán Wèigōng (i.e. Hán Qí 韓琦, famous general of the Northern Sòng 1008-1075) was as exception to this rule.
Whenever he talked about a petty person failing to respond properly to generosity, going against justice, or rebelling against him,
his speech would remain affable, and his spirit would remain balanced,
as if he was talking about a perfectly ordinary matter.
Wáng Zēng (Northern Sòng prime minister, Morohashi 07753) went twice to Dàmíng Prefecture, to replace Chén Yáozī.
When he had looked over affairs, he found that in the Prefecture a bridge had been destroyed.
He built it up, as it had been before, without changing anything.
Some vessels had been destroyed, and he replaced them all to the same number.
When there were inadequate things in the government, he glossed them over through indirect comments,
and in everything he covered up what was wrong.
When he moved to become governor of Luòshī (i.e. Luòyáng)
Chén Yáozī took over the government again.
He looked at things and he sighed and said:
"As for Mr Wáng, it is appropriate enough that he becomes prime minister.
I not reach his stature of broad-mindedness."
Chén Yáozī, because of those mutual suspicions of earlier times,
had imagined Wáng Zēngzài was bound bound to go back into the history of the place
and disclose what he had hidden.
Fù Xiànjiǎn (i.e. 傅堯俞, of Sòng times, see 傅獻簡公奏議-(宋)傅堯俞撰)said that Lǐ Hàng (Sòng prime minister, Morohashi 05789) was a self-controlled and level-headed man.
One day there was a madman who tapped Lǐ Hàng's horse and handed up a document
in which the madman attacked Lǐ Hàng's shortcomings.
Lǐ Hàng was all apologetic and said:
"Wait until I've got home, and I'll look at it in detail."
The madman then broke into furious laughter
followed behind the ruler's horse, and blurted out:
"Occupying a great position without being able to do any good for the world,
also being unable to withdraw, blocking the way all the time for men of worth,
don't you feel ashamed in your heart?"
Lǐ Hàng on his horse was in two minds about what to do, and finally he said:
"Several times I have asked to retire,
but because my lord (the emperor) has not yet gracefully acceeded to my request
I have until the end had no way of going against his wishes."
Lǚ Gōngzhù (collaborator with Sīmǎ Guāng), throughout his life, never engaged in any conflict about right or wrong.
When he found himself slandered
he never argued in his own defense.
When he was small he made an inscription on the right of his seat:
"When evil is done to you,
accept it with no ado."
In fact, at this early stage, he was in this way chastising himself.
Wáng Wǔgōng (i.e. 王德用, Sòng personality, Morohashi 07794)used much goodness of heart in dealing with gentlemen.
He cut an imposing figure, and left a deep impression on those who met him.
Even village boys and ladies in the street
as well as barbarians from foreign lands
all knew his name.
(At one point) the senior secretary to the prime minister Kǒng Dàofū and others
raised accusations against him, because of a certain matter,
so that Wáng Wǔgōng from his position in the Secret Office, and they rusticated him from the city.
They also demoted him
to become the governor of Suí Province.
The gentlemen of the land were all afraid on his behalf.
But Wáng Wǔgōng's behaviour as well as his facial expression was as placid as ever.
The only difference was that he did not receive guests any more.
After a long time, Kǒng Dàofū died,
and a visitor said to Wáng Wǔgōng:
"This bodes well for you." (Your enemy is dead.)
Wáng Wǔgōng said:
"Mr Kǒng had been taking up matters as duty required.
How should one say he harmed me?
The sad thing is that the court has lost the one straight-talking minister."
At that point the man who had spoken up (i.e. the visitor) got to feel shame for the rest of his life.
And the gentleman and dignitaries of the land admired Wáng Wǔgōng as a man of stature (French: envergure).
From the Posthumous Works of the Chéng Brothers (the Sòng dynasty philosophers):
The Master said:
Fàn Yáofū was a broad-minded man.
Some time ago I met him in Chéngdū.
At the time the man was an acting general in the army.
Someone spoke up in court about Fàn Yáofū at court,
so the court sent an emissary to put down incense at Mount Èméi,
but in fact this was in order to investigate Fàn Yáofū's work.
One day Fàn Yáofū was chatting to Chéng Yí
and Chéng Yí asked:
"I understand an emissary is around,
how can you be so much at your ease (that you have time to caht with me)?"
Fàn Yáofū said: "If I did not act like this (as if nothing had happened)
I would just be artificially restraining myself."
In the event, the emissary did indeed get angry
and he beat someone who reported on Fàn about the ears with his whip.
One of Fàn Yáofū's underlings named Xǐ told Fàn:
"This one episode is sufficient to block all the slander.
You will have a clean reputation at court." (You have something on the emissary.)
Fàn neither moved against the person who had leaked the news about his behaviour,
nor did he make a report on the transgression by the emissary.
His impressive broad-minded stature was like this.
The Hànlín scholar Lǐ Zōngè's father was Lǐ Fāng (famous Sòng prime minister and editor of Taipingyulan 太平御覽).
When Lǐ Fāng held political sway, Lǐ Zōngè kept far from political powerbrokers in order to avoid any suspicions (of factionalism).
He consorted with horsegrooms
and there was no way of telling the difference between him and any other impoverished man of letters.
One day,
Lǐ Zōngè met his father in the street,
and Lǐ Fāng sped past, not knowing that he was passing by his son,
shouting him out of the way and thus humiliating him.
From that time on Lǐ Zōngè, whenever he saw his father,
would invariably discreetly hide away.
He was afraid that if his father understood what was going on he would come to be ashamed of himself.
When Fù Yáoyú (mentioned above, of Sòng times) was (governor) in Xú
the previous governor had embezzled public funds.
Fù Yáoyú secretly made up for the loss
and before he had paid up the whole sum, he was himself deposed.
His successor wrote an official letter to Fù Yáoyú,
"You must pay up the sum of a thousand min-cash."
Fù Yáoyú exhausted his own means and in addition endebted himself in order to pay the sum.
After a long time
an investigation revealed the true facts
and it turned out that Fù Yáoyú had never been guilty of any abuse of money,
but to the end he never defended himself.
His Stoic acceptance of things and his refusal to enter into conflicts was like this.
Hán Qí 韓琦 (of Sòng times, often referred to in this book) was guarding Xiāng Province,
and because of the sacrifice to Confucius, he had to spend the night outside his normal abode.
A little thief entered his house,
held up a sharp knife and said:
"I cannot support myself,
so I seek support from you."
Hán Qí said:
"But the vessels on the table are worth hundreds of cash.
I'll give all that to you."
The little thief said:
"What I want is your head to give over to the people from the West."
Hán Qí stretched out his head.
The little thief bowed his head and said:
"They say that you are a man of uncommon stature.
That is why I came to tedst you.
The vessels on the table I shall take as a gift from you.
But I hope you will not leak this out to anyone!"
Hán Qí said:
"I promise I shall not tell anyone."
Afterwards,
the thief was accused of other crimes
and was about to be executed.
In the market place where he was to be executed he gave a complete account of the above story
and he continued:
"You see, I reckon that that after I died
it would be pitiful if the virtuous behaviour of Hán Qí would go unbeknownst to the world."
Péng Sīyǒng (Sòng dynasty official, Morohashi 04204), when he first offered himself as a candidate at the examinations,
was a poor man with no extra resources of any kind.
He just took along a few gold rings and settled down for a time in a hostel.
Some people who were also taking the exam passed by,
and they all asked him to take out the rings so they could take a closer look at them.
One of the strangers popped a ring into his sleeve.
Péng Sīyǒng noticed this but did not say anything.
All the strangers did not understand what had happened,
and they all kept looking for the ring, terrified.
Péng Sīyǒng said:
"The number of rings is just this. There is none missing."
When he was about to leave, the person who had put the ring in his sleeve bowed and raised his hand,
so that the ring fell on the floor.
All the strangers were full of admiration for Péng Sīyǒng's moral stature.
Zhào Qīngxiàn's (Sòng dynasty personality and writer) home was on a three-way crossroads,
and the place was very narrow.
His nephews wanted to do him a favour
and at a high price they bought the home of an old man next door
in order to expand their uncle's home.
When Zhào Qīngxiàn heard about this he was less than pleased,
and he said:
"My family has been this man's neighbour for three generations,
can I bear to abandon him?
And he gave orders to return the home to the old man without asking for the selling price back.
All this is something that is precious in the instincts of a human being.
When the Sòng dynasty minister Hán Qí led an army to pacify the Wǔ Province,
he wrote a letter at night
and he ordered a guard to stand next to him holding a candle for him.
When the guard was looking the other way,
the candle burnt Hán Qí's temples.
Hán Qí quickly rubbed the flames away with his sleeve
and continued to write his letter as before.
After a short while he turned his head
and there was already a new guard.
Hán Qí was afraid that the head of the guards would punish the culprit with bamboo lashes
giving a shout, he stared at the new guard and said:
"Don't change the guard!
The other man knows very well how to hold a candle"
Everyone in the army was full of admiration for this.
When Hán Qí (the Sòng minister) held Dàmíng Province
one day there was a man who handed up two jade cups
and said:
"A peasant found these when entered a collapsed grave.
Both outside and inside there isn't a flaw one could point to.
This is a superb treasure."
Hán Qí rewarded him with pure gold,
in fact with an precious toy. (This being much nore valuable than the jade, in fact.)
Every time he held a feast and called guests together
he would set up a table
cover it with a sliken table cloth
and place the jade cup on top of it.
One day he was inviting the water transport emissaries
and he was about to use this arrangement.
He poured the wine and encouraged the guests, sitting around him,
when suddenly one of the officials, by mistake, knocked over the table
and the jade cups were smashed.
The attending guests were terrified,
and the official in question lay flat on the floor waiting to be held criminally responsible for what he had done.
Hán Qí's facial expression did not change.
With a smile he told the guests in attendance:
"As a matter of principle, the completion and the destruction of things
have their definite time where they must occur."
Then, abruptly, he turned to the official and he said:
"You did this by mistake.
It was in no way deliberate.
What crime is there is this?"
When Fù Wénzhōng (i.e. Fù Bì, famous Sòng minister, Morohashi 0335) was young
there was someone who swore at him,
but it was as if Fù Wénzhòng did not hear it.
Someone else said:
"But he his swearing at you!"
Fù Wénzhōng said:
"I'm afraid he must be swearing at someone else."
The speaker went on to tell him:
"But he swears at you using the name of Fù such-and-such!"
Fù Wénzhōng replied:
"How do I know that there aren't others in the world with the same surname and name?"
Lǚ Měngzhèng (Sòng dynasty prime minister) was appointed appointed prime minister
and was about to enter the ancestral temple,
when a temple official stuck his finger out from below one of the curtains and said:
"And that little man is supposed to be prime minister?"
Lǚ Měngzhèng pretended he did not hear
But in the end
those in the procession wanted to find out about the surname and name of that temple official.
Lǚ Měngzhèng insisted that he would not go along with this
and he said:
"If I just hear his surname and name once,
I won't be able to forget it for the rest of my life.
I had better not hear it!"
Dí Wǔxiāng (famous Northern Sòng general) was vice general in Zhēndìng.
one day
he gave a feast in honour of Liú Wēimǐn,
and a certain Liú Yì was also a member of the party.
Now this Liú Yì was basically an uncultivated and a violent fellow.
He saw that actors were poking fun at Confucians
and he exclaimed with a sudden burst of anger:
"You little fellow, dare you talk like this?"
He kept insulting Wǔxiāng, never stopping,
toppled the dishes on the table and rose to his feet.
Dí Wǔxiāng, unperturbed, did not make the slightest movement,
just kept talking, smilingly, more and more warmly.
It was first when Liú Yì got home that he regretted what he had done,
but then Dí Wǔxiāng came to his gate to apologise for his own part.
Wáng Jí (Sòng courtier under Shénzōng 神宗) was Commander in Chief at Tiánchāi.
He went on a campaign with Liú Gàn (待考).
Wáng Jí did not speak a lot.
It was as if he was never able to move.
When he was lined up with Liú Gān in one and the same public arraignment
Wáng Jí never asked any questions.
He just used all his energies to perform his duties to the king.
In the end he destroyed the enemies of the state
and he rose to the rank of General Army Controller.
Wáng Wénzhèng (Morohashi 07800, author of famous 筆錄), the Chief of Staff, was a man of broad-minded stature,
and he never showed any anger.
When drink or food were imperfect or unclean
he would just not take any, that was all.
His family wanted to test his broad-minded stature,
and they put little pebbles in his meat gruel.
Wáng Wénzhèng just took the rice, that was all.
They asked him why he was not eating any gruel,
and he said:
"It just so happens I won't eat meat."
One day they mixed ink into his rice.
Wáng Wénzhèng looked at it and said:
"Today I'm not in the mood to eat this rice. You may serve some rice soup.
His associates were accusing other staff in front of him and said:
"The meat in the kitchen has been eaten by the kitchen staff,
there is not enough meat now. We beg you to sort this out.
Wáng Wénzhèng said: "How much do you think there was?"
They said: "There was one catty.
Now we are only getting half a catty to eat.
The other half was whittled away by the serving people."
He said: "If you can get to eat all of one catty, is that enough?"
They said: "If we can eat all of one catty we shall have enough."
He said: "From now on we calculate one catty and a half, and we shall be fine."
His refusal to make transgressions public was always like this.
At one point the main gate was ruined.
The man in charge pulled it out from the house and put in a new one.
In the meantime he opened a gate in the corridor through which one could get in and out.
Wáng Wénzhèng got to the side gate,
and since the gate was low, he lay flat on the saddle and crawled through with it.
He never asked about the gate.
In the end, when he again used the main gate, he also raised no questions.
One of his mulitary drivers
was taking leave when he had reached retirement age.
Wáng Wénzhèng asked: "You've looked after the horses for how many years?"
The driver said: "For five years."
Wáng Wénzhèng said: "But I was not aware that you were there!"
When the driver had just left, he called him back
and he said: "But aren't you Sir such-and-such?"
Then he gave him abundant presents.
In fact the man had been in charge of the horses every day,
but Wáng Wénzhèng had only seen the back of him
and he had never seen the face.
That is why he only got to know him when he saw the face.
Hán Qí (the frequently mentioned Sòng personality) was a man of uncommon stature.
By nature he was was generous
and he was not a man for petty rules or quick changes of mood.
He was famous for his achievements all over the world
his position was a leading one among the ministers,
but one did not ever see him ploeased;
he took upon himself the greatest of burdens,
he took unfathomable risks,
his person was in graver danger than a pile of raw eggs,
but one did not ever see him worried.
He was joyfully constant,
never swayed by any event or thing,
and throughout his life he never went in for polished speeches.
In his conduct of public affairs
when he stepping forward he would stand in court and talk with the various gentlemen and dignitaries,
when withdrawing he would rest in his home and talk to the members of his household:
all this conduct came from that one source of earnestness..
Some people had followed him for tens of years,
they had recorded Hán Qí's words and actions,
and together they had again and again studied these:
their outside appearance and inner purpose fitted together,
and there was nothing that did not fit together.
Fàn Chúnrén 范純仁 (Sòng dynaty person, second son of the famous Fàn Zhòngyǎn 范仲淹, Morohashi 09960) understood the proverb "With a stone from a different mountain one can work jade" to mean
that as for jade,
it is a warm and rich thing.
If you take two pieces of jade to polish each other
you are not going to succeed in the polishing.
You have to get hold of a thing from a different rough quarry,
first then you can polish up the jade.
It is like a man of superior character living together with a petty man
when he is being encroached upon by the petty man,
he will cultivate his own self-awareness and will fearfully avoid the company of that petty man.
He will move his heart and convey forbearance upon his nature,
he will increasingly guard against any vulgar interference.
In this way the guiding principles will emerge.
Hán Qí (the Sòng personality), when illustrating how one must handle the relations between the man of superior character and the petty man
made it clear that in all cases these needed to handled with earnestness.
But when one knows that someone is a petty person
then one just cultivates less profound relations with him, that's all.
Whenever an ordinary person is being cheated by a petty man
when he finds out he will show his insight and will ruin him.
Hán Qí alone was not like this.
His intelligence was indeed sufficient to understand that the petty man had cheated him,
however, whenever this happened to him
he would never openly show this on his face.
Chén Guàn (瓘, of Sòng times, Morohashi 12403)
was humble and mild by nature,
and he never got into conflict with things.
When he was discussing things with people
he mostly picked up the strong points of the other party
and although he saw their weaknesses
he never brought them out to their face.
He only subtly indicated his meaning in order to warn them.
People, for the most part, withdraw to reflect on themselves, would be ashamed of themselves, and would be full of admiration for him.
Chén Guàn was particularly fond of fnding praise for future generations,
as for every word or deed of these future generations
if he found something commendable in them
then he would praise it openly, and spread the good news,
and he would claim that he himself could never have done this.
Whenever my master (Chéng Yí 程頤 1033-1107) was talking to Sīmǎ Jūnshí (i.e. Sīmǎ Guāng 司馬光),
he would never expose any mistakes in his interlocutor.
Like Fàn Chúnrén 范純仁 (second son of 范仲淹）,
of ten possible cases he would only contest three or four, that is all.
My master said:
"Sīmǎ Guāng must count as having an ability to accept things that happen to him,
if everyone goes against him, he will never show any anger.
That is his admirable point.
When Hán Qí )the fequently mentionen Sòng dynasty personality) was in the Wèi government
one of his subordinates, Lù Chéng, handed up an official document,
but at the end of them he neglecte to write down the author's name.
Hán Qí covered the document with his sleeves,
looked up and talked with the man,
and little by little he rolled up the document
and as if nothing had happened he handed it over to him (for signing and proper resubmission).
Dù Yǎn (978-1057, Morohashi 05863) once said:
"Those who are in charge these days
tend to like to disclose small mistakes by their subordinates.
This is not an example of forgiveness.
When I was running Yǎn Province
among his district officials there was one who was heavily burdened with family problems and orginally poor.
So the taxes he collected he gave to his family,
and when the public taxes were not enough
then he was using even public funds.
Using as much as was necessary
he was making sure that they had enough.
In addition there was another person who created havoc
and who was a real greedy official.
And Dù Yǎn again said:
"I have run the Province for a long period of time,
I've raised people's position, and I have moved them, and I have taken care of them,
but I have never ruined the career of any official.
those who did not perform their duties,
I assigned specific tasks
to insure that they did not remain lazy.
Those who did not work diligently
I instructed about (the sources of) good and bad fortune,
and I encouraged them to turn over a new leaf.
Those who mended their ways were many.
There was no need to tie them down by the use of laws.
Chén Yáozuǒ (963--1044, Morohashi 12423) became ten times governor of a province,
and six times he was in charge of reassigning officials to new positions.
he was always stern with his subordinates
and he saw to it that others understood what he was doing, and feared his authority.
But when it came to those who had severely broken the law and carried their transgressions to extremes
he mostly was protective of them.
Therefore he never once degraded an official under his charge.
Hán Yì of Sòng times (high official under Zhēnzōng) visited all the office-holders in the Zhōngshū region
he gathered together these officials,
and about small offences he just showed his displeasure.
He said:
"Now there is peace in the world,
and the supreme ruler's attitude is that he desires even for insects and plants to find their proper places in the scheme of things,
the remarkable gentlemen he hopes will become ministers,
the next best he hopes will become assistant entourage,
and officials with at least more than two thousand dàn 石 of grain as a salary
he also hoped would take office in the Province districts.
Why lock people up in this generations of sages/world ordered by a sage?
Chén Xiāo (of Hàn times, Morohashi 12398) was a neighbour of Mín Jìbó's.
At night, Mín Jìbó stealthily moved the fence of Chén Xiāo's plot of land to increase his own.
Chén Xiāo saw what was happening.
He waited until Mín Jìbó has left,
and then he moved the fence a further meter and a half
thus further increasing Bó's plot of land.
Bó found out what what happening
and was ashamed to the point of panic.
On his own initiative he returned the land he had taken,
and added a further meter and a half for good measure.
The governor in charge, by name of Zhōu, held a high opinion of Chén Xiāo's moral qualities
he had a stone inscribed and a banner was exhibited in his village
the name of which became "Village of Justice"
Two commoner brothers of Yǐ Pǔmíng (待考) from Qīnghé
had been quarrelling over certain fields for several years in a row.
The governor, Sū Qióng (of Northern Qí times) instructed them:
"It is a privilege hard to obtain in this world
to have a brother;
what is easy to get hold of
is a piece of land.
Now if you get your piece of land
but lose your good relations as brothers, how would that help?
The brothers of Yǐ Pǔmíng kowtowed and begged to think about this abroad.
They separated for ten years, but then they returned to live together (both without the land they wanted).
A governor of Pěng District (impossible to identify) said:
"Just because of one morning's burst of anger one can lose one's life as well as one's relatives;
with the edge of an awl one can destroy one's whole family and ruin one's business.
So therefore one cannot but warn against divisive quarrels.
In general the origins of angry quarrels
are very trifling in the beginning,
but the resulting disasters are very great.
We call completely unstoppable
the waters of the Yangtse and the Yellow River,
long slim strings of silk
may in the end become a (strong) large web.
If a man, when it comes to these small beginnings, can stick firmly to forbearance and keep firm control of things,
then there will be no problems.
One's nature is like fire,
just as it flares up, it is quite easy to control,
but once the flames are proerly burning
then the fire will burn mountains and singe planes,
and there is no way to extinguish it.
That is something to be very much afraid of.
There is a common saying which goes like this:
"Go for forbearance, and again forbearance,
go for restraint, and again restraint,
without forbearance and restraint
small matters become large."
Just look how people nowadays enter angry strife and then litigation,
and how they end up losing their lives and their relatives.
If, when one is slighted by someone and pushed around one will invariably get angry
if, when one is slighted by someone and is infringed upon one will inevitably quarrel,
then that is an inability to show forbearance,
and then when one swears at someone, that man will swear back,
and when one beats someone, that man will strike back,
when one sues someone in court, that man will suo one back,
there will be mutual resentent and mutual enmity,
everyone will be making his business to win over everyone else.
When this victory-eager mentality once has flared up,
there is nothing that can stop it.
Losing one's life and one's relatives,
ruining one's family and destroying one's business all spring from this as their ultimate source.
The best strategy is, when you are about to get angry at the beginning, then to show forbearance regarding whatever it is,
then, when a little time has gone by,
you mind will surely have cleared up.
At this initial point when you have the urge to fight, then you must show forbearance regarding whatever it is
and if in the end others do you injustice
then you should slowly and according to all the rules of propriety, ask them what they are doing,
and if they do not go long with you, then at your own pace you may perfectly well take the matter to the authorities.
If you are taken to court,
you should act straightforwardly;
and when the going gets a little rough,
you also ought to be delicately indirect, so that you maintain the dignified moral sentiments in the neighbourhood.
In that way you will not damage your property
you will not wear out your spirit,
your personal attitude will be one of tranquility,
and others will also trust and admire you.
This is the method of tranquility and joy in this world of men.
If you quarrel, struggle, get angry, and compete for things,
you will lose your mind, use up your property
wait around in court buildings,
bow all over the place to court officials and magistrates,
get detained and put in fetters in prison,
you will spill your basic assets in the business of ruining yourself and your kin,
destroy your home and waste away whatever you own,
Isn't that a long way from being successful?
A governor of Yīng District said:
"When there is something the human mind is angry at
one is bound to have someone to quarrel with;
if one has someone to quarrel with
one is bound to expend energy on it.
If out of anger one quarrels, then one will reduce one's person,
if out of anger one enters litigation, then one will reduce one's assets.
It is on the basis of this that the person of superior character gains insight,
in accordance with the sǔn hexagram in the Book of Changes he controls anger."
The Àntújì says:
Léi Fú (of Sòng times) was a man from Yífēng.
He took the jìnshì degree,
and he fulfilled his official duties impeccably.
He was a generous man fond of virtue and rectitude.
Through the good offices of Prime Minister Shū(待考) he was given the honorary post of Senior Tutor to the Heir Apparent.
From the time of the gnerous Léi Wèi of Táng times down to Léi Fú there were eleven generations,
and in none of these was there any public litigation.
